content:
Although my blog isn't getting the amount of traffic/likes/interest that I expected I'm actually really happy for the amount of work I've been doing on it. I feel like I'm finally getting to a point where future article ideas just naturally come to me.

Take some time to appreciate your work. Every few weeks you should reflect on the recent work you've done and write it down. You will absolutely forget all of the achievements and only remember the struggles.

content:
Tired of API chaos? Contract-based APIs are the future, offering a structured and reliable way for applications to talk to each other.

This post explores the benefits of contracts and dives into popular technologies like Protocol Buffers and gRPC to help you build robust, maintainable APIs.

𝐊𝐞𝐲 𝐛𝐞𝐧𝐞𝐟𝐢𝐭𝐬:
• Improved developer experience
• Reduced errors
• Easier integration
• Streamlined development

𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧 𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐞 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐭𝐚𝐦𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐰𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐰𝐞𝐬𝐭 𝐨𝐟 𝐀𝐏𝐈𝐬!

https://sudorandom.dev/posts/api-contracts/

#grpc #protobuf #api #development #engineering

content:
I legitimately think our calendar system would be better with 13 28-day months plus a special day for new years (or two on leap years).

Think of it, days of the week will always be aligned to the months. No more need to print calendars for every year because the days of the week change..

28 days is much more aligned to the moon's (and women's) cycle.

No more trying to explain to kids why some months have 28, 29, 30, or 31 days. You know damn well this never made sense.

ALSO, months are kind of lame anyway. Some places (like Denmark) use week numbers, which make it much easier to communicate the exact day.

"saturday of week 32"

is much easier to communicate than

"August 10th which is a Saturday this year which is useful to know because it changes every year. by the way, have you heard of this calendar system that uses 13 28-day months?"

We can do better.

Also, let's scrap time zones.

content:
Eras that I think every dev goes through:

- 100% code coverage.
- TTD
- Everything is a functional test
- Mock everything
- Everything needs a comment
- imposter syndrome
- burnout every 5 months
- a library is the solution for every problem
- a cloud product is the solution for every problem
- a new microservice is the solution for every problem
- AI is the solution for every problem

content:
Tired of the limitations of REST APIs?

This article explores modern alternatives like GraphQL, gRPC, and WebSockets that can unlock a world of possibilities beyond REST for your web applications.

REST has served us well, but it's time to move on.

Learn about:

• The limitations of forcing real-world entities into rigid REST structures
• Why versioning in REST can be a nightmare for developers
• How inefficient JSON can be for data transfer
• Why OpenAPI specs aren't a silver bullet

Discover exciting new API design options:

• GraphQL: The "Choose Your Own Adventure" API for flexible data fetching
• gRPC: The "Cut the Drama" API for clear and efficient communication
• WebSockets: The go-to solution for real-time data updates
• Server-Sent Events (SSE): Simple server-to-client updates for live scores or notifications

The API landscape is ever-evolving. Don't be afraid to break free from REST and explore new possibilities!

See the full post here: https://sudorandom.dev/posts/restless/

Did I miss any good alternatives?

#webdev #api #graphql #grpc hashtag #websockets

content:
Protobuf is the contract that holds your gRPC microservices together. Wouldn't it be nice if you could detect when there is a mismatch of protobuf versions? Don't let version discrepancies break your gRPC services in subtle ways! Although clear versioning is important, it's not always easy to tell if all parts of your system are up-to-date. I made something that helps with this (if you happen to use ConnectRPC). I made an interceptor that detects when a ConnectRPC client or server is receiving responses or requests that include unknown fields.

You can read more about it here: https://sudorandom.dev/posts/unknownconnect-go/

And the project page is here: https://github.com/sudorandom/unknownconnect-go/

#grpc #connectrpc #api

content:
ConnectRPC unlocks the true potential of gRPC, bridging the gap between traditional web clients and your server without the need for complex gRPC proxies. Experience the simplicity of REST-like APIs alongside the power of gRPC and gRPC-Web - all in a single, streamlined deployment. Dive in and see how: https://sudorandom.dev/posts/connectrpc/

#grpc #web #golang
